comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We're looking for your help! Please help us identify the location in this photograph in the comments below.

comment.author: 54845211@N07
comment._content: The shadows indicate that we are looking west, so this is the SW corner of a numbered street and a lettered street. The angle of the street in the foreground is that of VA/PA/MA. Those appear to be tracks, so that pretty much makes it Penn. Using period real estate maps and the large institutional building at front/left as a clue narrows the possibilities to 18th & H NW, making the institution the Interstate Commerce Commission and the building in question the Hurley-Wright Building. Indeed, the building permits database indicates that a 12-story concrete, brick, and stone building was erected at 1800 H in 1918, which matches the style. The footprint on the map is marked as being 80 feet along 18th Street, which looks about right.

comment.author: 54010147@N07
comment._content: At the Library Of Congress we have photos of the building at www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=Railroad%20Adm.%20%20f81. The original captions identify it as "Railroad Adm and Civil Service Commission" which was housed in the Hurley-Wright building in 1923 (when this photo was taken).

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
The title and summary have been updated for this image. Thanks to everyone for the input and identification!

Susannah
Smithsonian Institution Archives
